image.altText: A man and a woman smile as they hold an infant.

items.synopsis: A 31-year-old man has been charged with two counts of murder (domestic violence offence) after police were called to a "confronting" scene in central Queensland.

title.children: Man charged with murder after mum, baby found dead in Rockhampton home

image.altText: Exterior gate at Risdon prison, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: The number of meetings potentially compromised by the covert police surveillance of a room at Tasmania's Risdon Prison could number in the hundreds, it has been revealed — with the matter described as a "massive breach of privacy" which demands a "comprehensive review".

title.children: Police put a camera and microphone in a prison meeting room for two months — now, those who may have been recorded want answers

image.altText: Man in white shirt standing behind a podium waves to the camera

items.synopsis: This parliamentary week involved a pitched battle over how many pages are in the Uluru Statement and a bold Coalition stand against cheaper drugs. But no one could stay grumpy when Kevin Rudd's official portrait was unveiled, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It was a tricky week in parliament for Anthony Albanese. Then Kevin Rudd made a comeback

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: The deaths were reported by Maui County as the devastating wildfire continues to rip through the island.

title.children: 'It's like an apocalypse': At least 36 killed, thousands displaced in Hawaii's Lahaina wildfires

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released her first public statement describing the harsh conditions of her imprisonment and how much she misses Australia.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The 'goddess of chaos' COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: A man with cap and white beard at a racing stables leans on a fence.

items.synopsis: The northern Tasmanian council that last year approved a kennel licence for trainer Anthony Bullock says it is now investigating him, after a similar racing integrity investigation.

title.children: Council confirms investigation into Tasmania's leading greyhound trainer over licence

image.altText: Water rushing through a broken wall down into a green valley

items.synopsis: Authorities were previously planning to blow up a part of the dam to prevent communities downstream from being inundated.

title.children: Dam bursts in Norway after days of heavy rain and flooding from Storm Hans

image.altText: A group of officers walking.

items.synopsis: Authorities say they have dismantled a large-scale illicit tobacco syndicate operating in south-east Queensland, seizing nearly 3 million illegal cigarettes and 380 kilograms of the drug.

title.children: Border Force seizes 3 million illegal cigarettes in Queensland raids

image.altText: Melissa Caddick missing

items.synopsis: Investors caught in Melissa Caddick's alleged Ponzi scheme receive their first payout, three years after the scandal came to light.

title.children: $3m given back to Melissa Caddick investors in first payout since alleged fraudster vanished

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines has stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why is China so keen to stop resupply ships reaching a dilapidated warship stuck on a South China Sea reef?

image.altText: A man speaks to the media outside court.

items.synopsis: The husband of an SA mum killed by a drunk P-plater who was speeding, on his phone, and on the wrong side of the road, tells an Adelaide court of the moments after the crash when he tried to save his wife.

title.children: Victim's husband slams killer driver's 'pathetic and cowardly' act after fatal crash

image.altText: Bill Shorten in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: The parliament has formally apologised to victims of the former government's unlawful Robodebt scheme. However, the motion — which criticised former ministers — was opposed by the Coalition.

title.children: Federal parliament apologises to Robodebt victims

image.altText: Aerial view of jail facility at Holtze, near Darwin.

items.synopsis: A patched member of the Mongols outlaw motorcycle gang has had at least 18 months added to his prison sentence, after unleashing a “particularly vicious” attack on a fellow prisoner.

title.children: Mongols member sentenced for 'particularly vicious' prison attack

image.altText: Workers and supporters of WGA protest outside Netflix offices in California.

items.synopsis: Hollywood's been hit with the biggest strikes in decades leaving unions in the US and Australia concerned about the dominance of movie studios and streaming platforms changing the way we watch our favourite shows and movies.

title.children: 'Fighting for the working class': How Hollywood's writers' strike is playing out in Australia

image.altText: A computer screen showing a TPG add

items.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of Australians face an extra cost to access emails after one of the country's largest internet providers announced plans to close down its in-house email service.

title.children: TPG Telecom to close down free email service, with thousands forced to pay extra cost

image.altText: Dingo Hill

items.synopsis: A woman has been bitten by a dingo on K'gari less than a month after a woman was mauled by a pack of the animals.

title.children: Woman bitten by dingo on K'gari hours after safety alerts about threatening behaviour sent out

image.altText: Picture of lamb with the American flag

items.synopsis: A group of cattle and sheep producers in the United States says Australian lamb imports are bringing its own industry to its knees and is petitioning for major restrictions that will also include New Zealand.

title.children: American lobby group pushes for import tariffs on Australian and New Zealand lamb

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman with a stern facial expression

items.synopsis: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price claims land councils are not effectively representing traditional owners, or delivering for communities, but a Northern Territory federal MP says they are already under significant scrutiny.

title.children: Calls for Senate inquiry into Aboriginal land councils stems from 'personal vendetta'

image.altText: A screenshot from a grainy VHS video shows Rose Hancock Porteous in a bright red silk shirt.

items.synopsis: Gina Rinehart's lawyers have sensationally accused her own late father of siphoning money to himself under pressure from his then-wife Rose Porteous to fund a "luxurious lifestyle".

title.children: Gina Rinehart's lawyer claims late father pressured by then-wife Rose Porteous to fund 'luxurious lifestyle'

image.altText: A composite of a boy and a taped-off sinkhole.

items.synopsis: Geologists say "potentially lots" of old goldmine shafts around a town in Victoria could be in danger of caving in due to heavy rainfall last year, but "we have no idea where they are".

title.children: Oliver fell into a sinkhole outside his school. Now there's fears more old goldmine shafts could open up

image.altText: drone image of shrubs shaped like a lizard

items.synopsis: An eco-cultural effort in southern WA depicting giant Indigenous totems of native animals is helping bring the landscape back to life.

title.children: Giant Aboriginal artworks years in the making sprout across WA

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A man holds a navy blue flag with white writing, standing behind police tape

items.synopsis: FBI agents shot the Utah man, who referred to himself as a "MAGA Trumper" and had posted online about plans to "clean the dust off the m24 sniper rifle", just hours before the US president was due to land in the state.

title.children: FBI shoots and kills man accused of threatening Joe Biden

image.altText: A close shot of Mr Butler's face, looking serious.

items.synopsis: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme.

title.children: Coalition withdraws attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme, asking for government to delay

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: An oil painting of Kevin Rudd in his Queensland home, a cat wanders on the table in front of him, a wall of books behind him.

items.synopsis: Kevin Rudd is now a permanent presence within the halls of Parliament House, with his official portrait joining those of other former PMs 10 years after he quit parliament.

title.children: Kevin Rudd re-enters parliament — as a painting

image.altText: A woman stands in front of microphones

items.synopsis: WA's health minister defends moving the state's new maternity hospital almost 20 kilometres away from its current location, as documents reveal issues with the initial plan.

title.children: 'No amount of consultation' could have changed government's mind on location of new maternity hospital

image.altText: A close-up of Leeanne Enoch  smiling with trees behind her

items.synopsis: Leeanne Enoch says the meetings for only First Nations staff were "standard cultural practice" and a way to gauge potential conflicts of interest.

title.children: Queensland treaty minister says LNP claim of 'segregation' over First Nations staff meetings is 'racist'

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week is looming as an important moment for Australian housing
